abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project outcome was
            unsatisfactory. Although the physical components were
            completed, ahead of time and under budget, results were
            mixed. The developmental strengthening of the Maharashtra
            State Electricity Board was marginal, unlikely to be
            sustained. Nevertheless, the project ensured the need for
            power sector restructuring, even though timing remains
            questionable. The key lessons drawn from this project,
            suggest that while state governments in India, exercise the
            operational control of the state electricity boards (SEBs),
            commercial decisions are not under the latter's
            control, hence a detrimental financial and commercial burden
            exists. Unless a private majority ownership takes control,
            revenues will continue to be unaccounted for. Project
            results confirm the position taken by the Bank, with respect
            to the power sector in the region, because despite previous
            attempts, the only sustainable solution remains to address
            the root of the problem, i.e., the politicization of
            decisions, non-technical losses due to theft, and, lack of a
            commercial culture, attainable only through structuring of
            the power sector at the national level. This would include
            corporatization, regulatory framework development, and
            tariff reforms, including privatization development.
            However, resettlement and rehabilitation plans were
            achieved; its success, attributed to self-relocation.
